explanation:
To simplify \( \frac{18}{30} \), the GCD of 18 and 30 is 6. Correct simplification: \( \frac{18 \div 6}{30 \div 6} = \frac{3}{5} \).

The student divided numerator and denominator by 2 instead: \( \frac{18 \div 2}{30 \div 2} = \frac{9}{15} \).

The error occurred because the student identified 2 as a common factor but failed to recognize 6 as the higher common factor. This caused partial simplification rather than full reduction. 

This aligns with the misconception of stopping at a suboptimal divisor (2) instead of iterating to the GCD (6). It differs from "forgot to simplify" (as partial simplification occurred) and unrelated to adding/subtracting errors. The core flaw was prioritizing an intermediate factor over the maximal one.
